comments.body:
I tried this which did not need any attachments (I don't think its that important to do the point span for synthetic):
```scala
def nameSpan(using Context): Span =
  if span.exists then
    val point = span.point
    if name.toTermName == nme.ERROR then Span(point)
    else if qualifier.span.start > span.start then // right associative
      val realName = name.stripModuleClassSuffix.lastPart
      Span(span.start, span.start + realName.length, point)
    else
      Span(point, span.end, point)
  else span
```

comments.body:
In ee4b125, I'm trying:

```Scala
        var acc = x
        var list = trees
        while (!list.isEmpty) do
          acc = apply(acc, list.head)
          list = list.tail
        acc
```

After tail-call optimization, the two versions are almost the same. Let's see if there is difference in benchmarks.
I don't think there will be. If anything, the tail recursive version should be faster since it does a single type test per iteration instead of one each in isEmpty, head, and tail.
In #9565, we get a slight speedup for Dotty.

A conceptual question: if `Infix` and `Using` are mutually exclusive, would it be better to use attachment for `Infix` as well to avoid creating the class `InfixApply`? Something like:

```Scala
def setApplyKind(kind: ApplyKind) = 
  putAttachment(untpd.ApplyKind, kind)
  this

def applyKind: ApplyKind =
  attachmentOrElse(untpd.ApplyKind, ApplyKind.Regular)
```
Yes, I think that might be better. I'll try that out.

comments.body: This is good for uniformity but why would this make any difference for type test safety warnings ?

The following code shows why it matters:

```Scala
trait Tree[-T]

class JavaSeqLiteral[T] extends Tree[T]

trait Type

class DummyTree extends JavaSeqLiteral[Any]

def foo1(tree: Tree[Type]) =
  tree.isInstanceOf[JavaSeqLiteral[Type]]   // error

foo1(new DummyTree)
```
Why drop only implicit methods that are followed by some other method type? Should this not be done for all implicit methods?

Note that I didn't write this code, I just moved it from tpd.scala That said, this drops methods whose result type is an implicit method, e.g. if you have `def foo(x: A)` and `def foo(x: A)(implicit y: B)`, it will pick the first alternative, which seems reasonable to me.
Do we have a test case that exercises this ?
The original test case was ErrorMessagesID, and I verified that the change here works for it. But c8265f1 fixes the problem by another means, so  it's no longer a test case.
I remember from #5892 there used to be a check `sameSourceFile` in the case, why it is not needed anymore?
Should it be `Tree[T]` here? Then I think the two `.derived.asInstanceOf[List[TypeTree]]` casts in `TreeOpsImpl.scala` wouldn't be needed.
`derived` only exist as untyped trees. Typed trees contain `derived$...` members instead. It would be pointless to keep typed `derived` trees around, as the info in them is never relevant.

comments.body: Was there a specific reason to add it as an extra method?

Performance. If we add a rare case, we only override `transformMoreCases`. Before the rare case was in the overridden `transform`. So every match had to first look at the rare cases before it would forward to `super.transform`.
So, why define this case here instead of in TypedTreeMap?
There is no `TypedTreeMap` and this addition did not seem sufficient reason to me to create one.  Mostly because I was worried that creating more indirections in tree maps would hurt performance.
I would add a comment describing which tag numbers can be reused and why.
üëç It's not clear for me why are they reused.
There's no re-use: NumTypeTreeTags is a counter, not a tag. I'll add a comment to make that clearer.

comments.body: We can use the same tags that are used in tasty. WDYT?
We could try, but then the switches will not be dense anymore, so will most likely not be implemented by a table switch.
Also, in that case unpickled trees would not have tags, so we could not use tags for e.g. typer.
